intro: Quercus nuttallii, commonly known as the Nuttall oak, is a deciduous tree native to the western United States. It typically grows to a height of 10–25 meters and is characterized by its lobed leaves that turn yellow in the fall. The tree produces small, acorn-like fruits that are an important food source for various wildlife species. Its bark is thick and fissured, providing a rugged appearance. Quercus nuttallii is often found in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments.
